texts.shortText:
Large, well-known and iconic species frequently photographed by divers. Disc cream to grey and decorated with radiating rows of tubercles, each surrounded by a black ring (hence common name). The 10 elongate, slender, flexible arms are each banded in black and cream and bear regular lateral branches, which in turn are divided into ever-finer branches.

Specimens usually seen clinging to reef pinnacles, seafans or similar prominent perches, arms widely outstretched to intercept passing food particles.

Global: Endemic to South Africa (records from other regions considered unreliable).

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.

A relatively uncommon species, but very large, striking and conspicuous and thus one of the best-known of all regional invertebrates. Depth range 11- 555 m and usually found with arms widely extended and perched prominently on reef pinnacles, or among other sedentary organism, especially seafans, with the arms facing into the current. When not feeding the arms are retracted and coiled.

Arms held up into the water column and orientated towards the current to form a parabolid ‘basket’ to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Food may include relatively large organisms, such as jellyfish, crustaceans and polychaetes. Prey are grasped by the slender end branches of the arms and periodically each arm is coiled towards the mouth and the food particles removed by passing the arm through the comb-like oral papillae. The tube feet do not play a role in food transport, as in other brittle-stars.

Details unknown for this species, but sexes separate and basket stars are normally broadcast spawners that discharge eggs and sperm into the water column, where they develop as planktonic larvae before settling back onto suitable substrata. Juveniles are sometimes found clinging to the adults, but this is simply because they form suitable substrata and is not an indication of brooding.

Basket stars are unmistakable due to their branched arms and this species is by far the most common one seen by divers and is easily recognized by the white, black-ringed tubercles on the disc. There are, however, several other regional basket–star species, including the plain-coloured A. hirtus, which is confined to northern KwaZulu-Natal, and the pinkish brown to red Gorgonocephalus pustulatum, which occurs in deeper waters of 75-860 m.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 230).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 131).

Olbers, JM, Griffiths, CL, O'Hara, TD & Samyn, Y (2019). Field guide to the brittle and basket stars (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) of South Africa ABC Taxa, 19, 1–346 (p. 61).
